message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Precursor B-cell leukemia accounts for about 85% of childhood ALL cases, and CD19 and CD10 are commonly expressed on the surface of the malignant cells. TdT (terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase) is a common marker for all lymphoid cells, but is not specific to precursor B-cell leukemia. The other options are not associated with precursor B-cell leukemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Precursor B-cell leukemia is the most common type of ALL, and positive immunostaining for CD19 and CD10 are indicative of precursor B-cell lineage. TdT is a marker for both B and T-lineage lymphoblasts, HER-2 is not specific to any lymphoblast lineage, and CD30 and CD15 are markers for Hodgkin lymphoma and some T-cell lymphomas, but not for ALL. CD4 and CD5 are T-cell markers and not indicative of precursor B-cell lineage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The diagnosis of ALL is supported by the bone marrow aspiration results, and PETECHIAE suggest a low platelet count. Positive immunostaining for CD19 and CD10 would identify precursor B-cell leukemia.

We refer to the National Cancer Institute website for help. Precursor B-cell ALL is characterized by the expression of CD19, CD10, and TdT. CD19 and CD10 are B-cell markers, while TdT is a marker for early lymphoid precursors. Therefore, positive immunostaining for CD19 and CD10 would support a diagnosis of precursor B-cell leukemia, as seen in option (B).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Precursor B-cell leukemia is characterized by the presence of CD19 and CD10, making option B the correct answer. TdT and HER-2 are not specific to B-cell leukemia, while CD30 and CD15 are associated with Hodgkin lymphoma and CD4 and CD5 are associated with T-cell leukemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only CD19 and CD10 are markers for B-cells, and their positivity would support a diagnosis of precursor B-cell leukemia, which is the most common type of childhood ALL. TdT is a non-specific marker for lymphoblasts, HER-2 is a breast cancer marker, CD30 and CD15 are markers for Hodgkin lymphoma, and CD4 and CD5 are markers for T-cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Precursor B-cell leukemia is the most common subtype of ALL, and the presence of CD19 and CD10 would support its diagnosis. TdT is present in both T and B cell precursors, HER-2 is not a marker for leukemia, and CD30 and CD15 are more commonly found in Hodgkin lymphoma. CD4 and CD5 are markers for T cell lymphoma/leukemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Precursor B-cell leukemia is the most common subtype of childhood ALL. Positive immunostaining for CD19 and CD10 would support a diagnosis of precursor B-cell leukemia. TdT is a marker for immature lymphocytes but is not specific to any subtype of lymphoblastic leukemia. HER-2, CD30, CD15, CD4, and CD5 are not associated with a diagnosis of ALL or precursor B-cell leukemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Precursor B-cell leukemia is characterized by the expression of CD19 and CD10 antigens on leukemic cells, which are positive in option (B). TdT and HER-2 are expressed in lymphoblasts but are not specific for precursor B-cell leukemia. CD30 and CD15 are expressed in Hodgkin lymphoma and may be found in other lymphomas, but not in ALL. CD4 and CD5 are expressed in T-cell lymphoma, but not in precursor B-cell leukemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD19 and CD10 are both markers of precursor B-cell leukemia. TdT and HER-2 are not specific to this diagnosis, and CD30 and CD15 are markers for Hodgkin’s lymphoma. CD4 and CD5 are markers for T-cell leukemia.
